text_markup:
[072] Diary  
Antwerp August 6 1891

[073] Diary  
August 7 1891. Antwerp  
Discussed difference between {Belgians|001|ethnic group} and {Hollanders|002|ethnic group}. Is it due to the hold of the {Catholic Church|003|institution} in {Belgium|004|country}?  
Read “L’Intruse” by {Maeterlinck|005|person},and compared it with {Mrs. Augusta Webster|006|person}’s “Auspicious Day.”

Aug. 8 Antwerp The Hague 1891  
Read Vol. V of Journal de {J. Goncourt|007|person} at breakfast. Went to {Musée|008|institution} and saw {Titian|009|person} and {Rubens|010|person} and {Flemings|011|ethnic group}. Sketched ears. After lunch went to the {Cathedral|012|place} to see {Rubens|010|person} and to {S. Jacques|013|place}, where there is a finer {Rubens|010|person}. Sacristan most grumpy - pulled curtain over pictures and found it incredible that anyone should  
[074]  

want to look at a picture a whole quarter of an hour. Marched uneasily up and down asking, “Est-ce fini?” Read {Baedeker|014|person} in train. Hist. {Holland|015|country}, Rise of {Flemish|016|ethnic group} and {Dutch|017|ethnic group} art.

Sunday, Aug. 9. 91. The Hague  
Went to {Baron Steengracht|018|person}’s collection. Saw {Rembrandt|019|person}’s {Bathsheba|020|artwork (concept)} xx. Very large {Jan Steen|021|person} (family group) large portrait of a boy by {Metsu|022|person}. Finest {A. Brauwer|023|person}, drinking scene with portraits of himself, {Franz Hals|024|person}, etc. Afternoon went to {Museum|025|institution}. Saw {Rembrandt|019|person}’s {Presentation in Temple|026|artwork (concept)}.  
xxx {Vanmeer|027|person} von Delft, water and houses.  
{Paul Potter|028|person} - {Bull|029|artwork (concept)}. This is a wonderful picture, painted to be the exact texture of the skin of the different animals. [075] A paradox in paint, for, although it is exactly like, the effect is not at all as we see it. {P. P.|028|person} died before 30. Interesting speculation as to what he might have become, with this wonderful skill with the brush. Saw Italian pictures.  
Monday August 10. 1891. s’Gravenhage  
Went to {Museum|025|institution}. Sketched {Sodoma|030|person} - saw other pictures, especially {Van Meer van Delft|027|person}.  
Went to {Leyden|031|city}. Walked about the town. Saw, after infinite difficulty, about a dozen sketch-books of {Hokusai|032|person}. Bought {Motley|033|person}’s {Dutch Republic|034|book}.and read introduction. Dined at the restaurant {Van Pijl|035|restaurant}. 4 francs. Very good. Took notes and discussed {Motley|033|person} in evening.  
Read {La Princesse Maleine|036|literary work (concept)} by {Maeterlinck|005|person} of {Bruxelles|037|city}.

[076]  

Tuesday Aug. 11. 91. s’Gravenhage  
Read {Motley|033|person} while dressing, {Goncourt|007|person} at Breakfast. Went to {Museum|025|institution} and  
sketched {Sodoma|030|person} again. Went to {Delft|038|city}. Saw Renaissance {Staathuis|039|building} and {Church|040|place}  
with Renaissance tomb of {William of Nassau|041|person}. Compared it with tomb in  
{Salisbury Cathedral|042|place}. Saw some quaint old houses. Looked for view which {Vanmeer|027|person}  
painted, but didn’t find it. Liked the town of the {Groote Kerk|043|place}. Evening strangely  
blue and violet. Read {Motley|033|person}.

[077] Wednesday. Aug. 12. 91. {Amsterdam|044|city}.  
Came from The Hague here. Read {Motley|033|person}. Went to {Museum|025|institution}. Saw “{Night Watch|045|artwork (concept)}” {B. B.|046|person} said it was a poet’s attempt to translate a commonplace subject into verse, and that it was told better and more appropriately, on the whole, in the good prose of {Van du Helst|047|person}, {Jardin|048|person}, etc. Saw a {Vermeer von Delft|027|person} and other {Rembrandts|019|person} and {Franz Hals|024|person}. Very tired. Read more {Motley|033|person}. Walked in {Kalverstraat|049|street}. Discussed the ways of writing history, epic and documental.

Thursday. Aug. 13.  91. {Amsterdam|044|city}  
Went to {Rijks Museum|050|institution} and saw {Rembrandt|019|person} {Old Woman|051|artwork (concept)} -{Syndics|052|artwork (concept)} - {Night Watch|045|artwork (concept)}. {Franz Hals|024|person}, {Portraits|053|artwork (concept)} and {Regents piece|054|artwork (concept)}, {Van du Meer|027|person}. {Van du Helst|047|person}. {Pieter de Hooghe|055|person}, {Van du Meer|027|person}. {Jan Steen|021|person}.  
[078] {Paul Potter|028|person}, etc. {Scoorel|056|person}. Saw a wonderful majolica plate, with a round representation of a scene somewhat similar to {Botticelli|057|person}’s “{Calumny|058|artwork (concept)}”. Very Timote-esque. The coat of arms was like this:[drawing]  
Lunched at {Krasnapolski’s|059|restaurant} - good coffee. Went to the {Six gallery|060|institution} ({Heerengracht 511|061|address}) and saw two {Vanmeer van Delft|027|person}’s - a woman pouring out water, and a street scene. This makes 11 of his pictures which {B.|046|person} has seen, e. g., 1 at the Hague,  

[0079]  
1 in the {Rijks Museum|050|institution} here, 2 in the {Six Collection|062|collection} (4), 2 at {Dresden|063|city} (6), 1 at {Berlin|064|city} (7), 1 at {Frankfurt|065|city} (8), 1 in {Vienna|066|city} (9), 1 in the {Borghese|067|institution} (10), 1 in the {Louvre|068|institution} (11).  
A wonderful {Rembrandt|019|person} ({portrait of Burgomaster Six|069|artwork (concept)}) done very much in {Franz Hals|024|person} manner. A splendid {Franz Hals|024|person} portrait of a man. Some {Cuyps|070|person}, {Terborgs|071|person}, {Jan Steens|021|person}, etc. A large {Paul Potter|028|person}, man on horseback, and a small one of cows.  
Read {Motley|033|person} and de {Goncourt|007|person}. Enjoyed the {Palace|072|building}. {Dutch Renaissance|073|art movement}, very harmonious and nice. Studied {German|074|language}. Wrote letters. Sent “{Maleine|036|literary work (concept)}”to {Miss Bradley|075|person} and {Miss Cooper|076|person}.

[080] Friday August 14. 1891.  
Read {Motley|033|person} going to {Haarlem|077|city}. Spent 2 1/2 hours in the {Museum|025|institution}, studying {Frans Hals|024|person}, etc. We were perfectly fascinated with the two pictures nos. 77 & 78, painted in 1664- in a manner suggestive of {Zorn|078|person} and {Carrière|079|person}, but even more modern than either! Compared him to {Shakespeare|080|person}. Also found figures and treatment which {Rembrandt|019|person} must have copied.  
The best {Terburg|071|person} - a {Family Group|081|artwork (concept)} - was painted very much like a {Courtois|082|person}. A landscape by {Van der Velde|083|person} was like a Hampstead Heath scene by {Constable|084|person} - but better! The {Cornelius van Haarlems|085|person} were all [081] interesting, and the pictures by {Jan de Braij|086|person}, while under {Frans Hals|024|person}’ influence, were very good. A {Regents picture|087|artwork (concept)} by {Pot|088|person} was also extremely good, and some portraits by {Verspronck|089|person}.  
Compared evolution of {Hals|024|person} to {Velasquez|090|person}, beginning where {Titian|009|person} left off.  
Went to {Fodor Museum|091|institution} - an absolute fraud, 1 small {Meissonier|092|person} and a slight sketch  
by {Watteau|093|person}.  
Walked through {Ghetto|094|neighborhood}.  
Saturday Aug. 15. 91.  
A day in train from {Amsterdam|044|city} 9. 30 to {Hanover|095|city} 8. 50. Missed connections. Very hot and somewhat dusty.  
Read {Motley|033|person} all day and studied {German|074|language}.  
<BLOCKBREAK/>

[082] Sunday August 16. 1891. {Brunswick|096|city}  

Came from {Hanover|095|city} -studied {German|074|language} in train and began {Tolstoi|097|person}’s “{Wandelt im Licht|098|literary work (concept)}.”{Gallery|099|institution} closed. Saw town and churches and very nice recent buildings in Renaissance style, i. e. - new {Schloss|100|building}, {Theater|101|venue}, {Police Court|102|building}, etc. In the {Dom|103|place} the tomb of {Henry the Lion|104|person} and {Matilda|105|person} his wife (done about 1200) was very remarkable and beautiful. Her face was particularly lovely, and as well modelled as anything Greek!! Found it hard to understand.  
At breakfast discussed the advantages, to a writer, of having no traditions to contend with - compared {Dumas fils|106|person} and {Ibsen|107|person}. {Tolstoi|097|person} and the {Russian novelists|108|group} with the {Americans|109|ethnic group}. Also the skill the rich get in objects of [083] household art, such as furniture, tapestry, carpets, etc., but the rarity of their becoming connoisseurs in the higher arts. {Goncourt|007|person} puts it perfectly in his entry for samedi, 20 février 1875 “Les gens riches, il leur arrive parfois d’avoir du goût dans les porcelaines, dans les tapisseries, dans les meubles, dans les tabatières, dans les objets d’art industriel … il semble vraiment qu’aux richaios, sauf de très rares exceptions, est défendu le goût de l’art supérieur, - de l’art fait par les mains, qui ne sont plus des mains d’ouvrier.”  
This is especially true of {Americans|109|ethnic group}, who really furnish their houses perfectly. However, they as buy good {French|110|ethnic group} pictures, or perhaps it is that they buy {French|110|ethnic group} pictures, and therefore can’t help getting good ones.

[in {Bernhard|046|person}’s hand]  
[084] Monday August 17. 9  
Went to the {gallery|099|institution} in the forenoon, and found that a hail-storm a month ago had smashed the glass-roofs of the large halls, and that the pictures in them therefore were invisible. But we told the custodian we must see them even in the dark. He took us on tiptoe to the {Palma|111|person}, and left us at our request. As we were going out we bumped against two officials. Mutual surprise. They tried to be indignant, then assured us we had risked our lives, because glass was still falling from the roofs. Told them they must know well that when you [0087] come on purpose to see pictures you did not mind risking your life. That disarmed them, and the younger was liebenswürdig enough to offer to take us through those same halls with a lantern.  
In this way we had a glimpse of two pictures that change one’s idea of their painter. One is a portrait by {Rubens|010|person} painted with almost the readiness, and sweat of {Frans Hals|024|person}. Furthermore, it is the only portrait by {Rubens|010|person} I have seen in which {Rubens|010|person} sinks himself. The other picture is {Stien|112|person}’s {Wedding-Contract|113|artwork (concept)}. The bride [088] and bride groom are charming beyond words.  
Other things never to be forgotten are the {Vermeer|027|person} and some of the {Rembrandts|019|person}.  
The {Vermeer|027|person} had that wonderful purity and tenderness of colouring which makes his work seem so much like the finest porcelain. In this as in the other pictures, the same light blue, the same tints of sage and pea green, and the same effects of atmosphere.  
The most fascinating {Rembrandt|019|person} is the landscape. One would like to know where he got such a landscape. It is a scene for some strange mysterious tale in {Stevenson|114|person}’s best fashion. Scarcely [089] less impressive is {Christ and the Magdalen|115|artwork (concept)}, neatly and clearly done, but treated in a wonderfully, religious way. The figure of {Christ|116|person} at any rate is full of that humility, and sense of wonder at his own self that {Rembrandt|019|person} more than once gives to the face and form of {Jesus|117|person}. The {Magdalen|118|person} is a {Dutch|017|ethnic group} woman of {Rembrandt|019|person}’s own time. Very interesting also are two portraits of {Rembrandt|019|person}’s earliest days, one of {Hugo Grotius|119|person}, a clean, fresh bit of painting, and one of {Grotius|119|person}’ wife. Her portrait we should scarcely have known for [090] a {Rembrandt|019|person}. It is so firm and free from effects of atmosphere.  
Finally I shall scarcely forget a little landscape by the elder {Vermeer|027|person}, a thing severe, quiet, with plenty of sky and spaciousness.  
In the afternoon we were in the fast express to {Berlin|064|city}, reading {Motley|033|person} and studying {German|074|language} as we rushed thro’ the pretty towns, or past woods of white birch.  
[0087-0088: small notes written by {Bernhard|046|person} using a fountain pen with an Italic nib]  
[recto 0087]  
Some people answer as if they were shutting the door with a bang.  
Mothers …  
[verso 0088]  
{Primavera|120|artwork (concept)}. {Venus|121|person}-type of {Judith|122|person} and {Fortezza|123|person}, keys left hand as in latter. {Mercury|124|person} and all flesh tints as in {Sebastiano|125|person} of {Berlin|064|city}.  
Drapery of {Venus|121|person} breasts and sleeves as in {Judith|122|person}.  
With this goes well the {Madonna with six saints|126|artwork (concept)}; in the hands are same.  
{Michael|127|person} and {John Polagologos|128|person}.  

{Feminine saint|129|person} of type of 3 dancing women. This is on way to coronation in the landscape as in {Venus|121|person} of ____.  
[in left margin] Spirit same ____ as child in {Madonna with 6 saints|126|artwork (concept)}.  
[from here on in {Mary|130|person}’s hand]  
[090] Tuesday Aug. 18. 91. {Berlin|064|city}  
Breakfast at {Bauer’s restaurant|131|restaurant}.  
Went to {Gallery|099|institution} - - - - - - - - - - ! ! 10-3.  
Walked in {Thiergarten|132|park}. Read {Layard|133|person}, etc., in the evening.

[091] Wednesday, Aug. 19. 1891  
Went early to {gallery|099|institution} and went carefully through the {Venetian School|134|art movement} from {Gentile da Fabriano|135|person} and {Antonio Vivarini|136|person} to {Tiepolo|137|person}. Also the {Veronese school|138|art movement}.  
Thursday August 20. 1891. {Berlin|064|city}  
{Florentine School|139|art movement} at the {gallery|099|institution} - As we were looking at a fake “{Pisanello|140|person}”, an {American|109|ethnic group} young man asked why it was fake. We were too busy to stop, but we asked him to lunch. His turned out to be from {New Brunswick|141|city}, and his name was {Van Dyck|142|person} - a circumstance which naturally led him to take [092] an interest in pictures!! He had rather good taste, but he was oppressed with profound scepticism. He said that the pictures were all so repainted that the ascriptions were a mere matter of guess-work. In fine, he turned out to be the sort of person who knows too much to want to learn, and too little to teach, or even to sympathize. Went to the {Nationalgallerie|143|institution}.  
{Herr Klinsmann|144|person} dined with us and we walked in the {Thiergarten|132|park}. We discussed the {Jews|145|ethnic group} in {Berlin|064|city}.  
Friday. Aug. 21. 1891. {Berlin|064|city}  
{Ferrarese|146|ethnic group} and {Milanese|147|ethnic group} Schools at the {Gallery|099|institution}. Went to {museum|025|institution} upstairs and [093] {Tschudi|148|person}’s study.  
{Herr Klinsmann|144|person} took us to the {International Exhibition|149|event}, where there were paintings by every school but the only good one, the {French|110|ethnic group}. {Böcklin|150|person} had an absurd “{Susanna and the Elders|151|artwork (concept)}”, as modern old ___ Jews. {Berenson|046|person} said he would like to see the {Bible|152|book} illustrated by {Böcklin|150|person}. The {Spanish|153|ethnic group} painters struck me as delightful, particularly {Villegas|154|person} and {Beuliure y Gil|155|person}.  
Came from {Berlin|064|city} to {Dresden|063|city}. {Motley|033|person} and {German|074|language}.

{Dresden|063|city} Saturday Aug. 22. 91. {Hotel Rheinischerhof|156|hotel}  
Went to {gallery|099|institution} ------ !!  
Met {Walter Cope|157|person}, {Signor Costa|158|person} and the {Hon. Mrs. Bontine|159|person} there. Saw  
{Belottos|160|person} with {Costa|158|person}.  
Read {Motley|033|person} and de {Lisle Adam|161|person} in the afternoon. Called on “{Michael Field|162|person}” and found them gone to the {hospital|163|institution}, {Miss Cooper|076|person} having the {Scarlet Fever|164|disease}. Poor things!  
Went to {Das Rheingold|165|musical work (concept)} in the evening, and enjoyed it very much.  
{Dresden|063|city} {Sunday|166|day} {August|167|month} {23|168|day} {1891|169|year}  
{Gallery|099|institution} in morning with {Costa|158|person}. Read {Bonhomet Triboulet|170|literary work (concept)} by {Villiers de Lisle Adam|161|person}. x {Restaurant Gneist|171|restaurant} [added in blue ink]  

{Dresden|063|city} {Monday|172|day} {August|167|month} {24|173|day}. 91.  
{Gallery|099|institution} in morning. Called on {Michael Fields|162|person} at {Stadt Krankenhaus|174|institution} [095] where {Miss Cooper|076|person} is ill with {Scarlet Fever|164|disease}. Went to {Die Walkyrie|175|musical work (concept)} in evening.

{Dresden|063|city} {Tuesday|176|day} {Aug|177|month}. {25|178|day}. 91.  
{Gallery|099|institution} with {Costa|158|person} in morning. Called on {Michael Field|162|person} in afternoon.  
{Concert|179|performance event} on {Terrace|180|place} in evening.  
{Motley|033|person} and {Villiers de Lisle Adam|161|person} “{Histoires insolites|181|literary work (concept)}”.  
{Wednesday|182|day}, {Aug|177|month}. {26|183|day}. 91. {Dresden|063|city}  
{Gallery|099|institution} with {Costa|158|person}. Met {Florence Dike|184|person}’s friend, {Lizzie Johnston|185|person} and her family. Discussed “{Botticelli|057|person}” {Madonna|186|artwork (concept)}. {Costa|158|person} thinks it genuine, {B. B.|046|person} not. Went to hear {Siegfried|187|musical work (concept)} in evening.

[096] {Dresden|063|city}. {Thursday|188|day} {August|167|month} {27|189|day}. 1891  
Went to {Gallery|099|institution} and read {Correggio|190|person} article and discussed it. Called on {Michael Fields|162|person}, who were enthusiastically reading “{Parsifal|191|musical work (concept)}.”{M.|130|person} felt very ill in afternoon. Both sleepy in evening.

{Dresden|063|city}. {Friday|192|day} {Aug|177|month}. {28|193|day}. 91.  
{Gallery|099|institution} in morning. Took notes of pictures. Called on {Miss Bradley|075|person} ({Michael Field|162|person}) in the afternoon. Went to {Götterdämmerung|194|musical work (concept)} in the evening and enjoyed it even more than all the others. {B.|046|person} remarked that {Wotan|195|person} was unusually [097] sensible for a god - for he retired when he perceived that he was obsolescent. {B|046|person} shaved off his beard!!!!  
* {Dresden|063|city} {August|167|month} {30|196|day}. 1891.  
Took 9. 20 train to {Pötscha|197|place} and walked to the {Bastei|198|landmark} through fresh, mushroom smelling pine woods. After lunch we started to walk to {Shaudan|199|place} but took a cul-de-sac road which landed us in a beautiful woodland temple. Walked back to {Rathen|200|place} and thence to {Pötscha|197|place}, just catching the train. The day was warm and fresh, and the sunlight enchanting. It was a day to remember all our lives. As we got off the train {B.|046|person} saw preparations which made him think they were about to commit a statue in the square.  
[098] {Dresden|063|city}. {Aug|177|month}. {31|201|day}. 1891. {Monday|172|day}  
Went to the {Gallery|099|institution} in morning and saw all the pictures, including {Dutch|017|ethnic group}.  My favourites are: {Venus|121|person}. {Giorgione|202|person} 2 {Paul Veroneses|203|person}. {Sistine Madonna|204|artwork (concept)}. {St George|205|person}. {Dosso|206|person} {Mars and Venus|207|artwork (concept)}, {Garofalo|208|person}. {Madonna Lotto|209|artwork (concept)}. Two panels {Ercole Roberti|210|person}. {Adoration|211|artwork (concept)} {Francia|212|person}. {Dream|213|artwork (concept)}. {Dosso|206|person}. {Justice|214|artwork (concept)}. {Dosso|206|person}. {Portrait of a Man|215|artwork (concept)}. {Titian|009|person}. {Jacob and Rachel|216|artwork (concept)}. {Palma|111|person}. {Santa Conv|ersazione|217|artwork (concept)}, {Palma|111|person}. {Annunciation|218|artwork (concept)}. {Cossa|219|person}. and many more, too numerous to mention. Paid our last call on {Michael Fields|162|person} at {Krankenhauss|174|institution} in the midst of a tremendous thunderstorm. Came back and packed [099] and read {Morelli|220|person} on {Munich|221|city} and {Robertson|222|person}’s {Charles V|223|person}. Discussed local {Christianity|224|religion}. {B.|046|person} shaved off his moustache!

{Regensberg|225|city} {Sept|226|month}.  1. 1891.  
 {Hotel Goldner Kreuz|227|hotel}, {Regensberg|225|city}  
An old inn. Delightfully large room.  
Pleasant journey from {Dresden|063|city}, 8. 45 to 5. 45. Finished {Goncourt|007|person}’s {Journal|228|publication}, read {Pierre Loti|229|person}’s “{Le Livre de Pitié et de la Mort|230|literary work (concept)},”et {Villier de Lisle Adam|161|person}’s “{Histoires insolites|181|literary work (concept)}.”Studied {German|074|language}. Read {Charles V|223|person}. Reached {Ratisbon|231|city} in time for a sunset on bridge over the {Danube|232|river}. Saw {Cathedral|012|place}, which had resemblances to {Notre Dame de Paris|233|place}. Late {Gothic|234|art movement} but on the whole good - for {Gothic|234|art movement}! Sent notes on {Frankfort|235|city} to {Michael Fields|162|person} in evening.  
<BLOCKBREAK/>

[100] {Journal des Goncourts|228|publication}.  
 {IIem Série|236|series} - {II Vol|237|volume}.  
{10 Jan|238|date}. {1872|239|year}. Aujourd’hui, chez le {français|110|ethnic group}, le journal a remplacé le catéchisme. Un premier {Paris|240|city} de {Machin|241|person} ou de chose devient un article de foi, que l’abonné accepte avec la même absence de libre examen que chez le {catholique|242|person} d’autrefois trouvait le mystère de la {Trinité|243|concept}.  
{16 Jan|244|date}. {1872|239|year}. Rien ne m’agace comme les gens qui vraiment vous supplier de leur faire voir des choses d’art, qu’ils touchent avec mes mains irrespectueuses, qu’ils regardent avec les yeux ennuyés.  
{1 Sept|245|date}.  {1873|246|year}. Après une affreuse migraine [101] je rêvais, cette nuit, que je me trouvais dans un endroit vague et indéfini, comme un paysage du sommeil. Là, se mettait à écurie un danseur comique, dont chacune des poses devenait derrière lui, un arbre gardant le dessin ridicule et contorsionné du danseur.  
[102] {20 Jan|247|date}. {1876|248|year}. Hier soir, dans le fumoir de la {princesse|249|person}, au causait de {Rossini|250|person}, quelqu’un parle d’une lettre écrite par lui à {Paganini|251|person}, le lendemain de sa première audition, lettre dans laquelle le {maestro|252|person} est tout entier. Il lui disait qu’il n’avait pleuré que trois fois dans sa vie: une première fois, lorsqu’il avait eu son premier opéra sifflé; une seconde fois, lorsque, dans un partie avec ses amis, il avait laissé tomber dans le {lac de Garde|253|lake}, une dinde truffée; enfin la troisième fois, en l’entendant la veille.  
{3 Juillet|254|date} {1870|255|year} …il faut pour faire quelque chose de bon littérairement, que tous les sens soient des fenêtres grandes ouvertes.  
<BLOCKBREAK/>

[103] {Goldner Kreuz|227|hotel} {Ratisbon|231|city} {Wednesday|256|day}. {Sept|226|month}.  2. 1891.  
Breakfast of grapes and
